chapter: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 58-year-old male patient presents with difficulty in urination and reports a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. Upon examination, the neurologist suspects an issue with autonomic innervation to the urinary bladder. What are the root values for the sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation of the urinary bladder?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sympathetic: T10-L2; Parasympathetic: S2-S4 Explanation: Urinary bladder is innervated by the vesical plexus, which comprises both sympathetic and parasympathetic fibers, involving both motor and sensory functions. Sympathetic innervation controls bladder filling , whereas the parasympathetic innervation controls bladder emptying. Somatic innervation is responsible for the voluntary control of urination. Type of Innervation Nerves Function Parasympathetic Nerve Fibers (S2, S3, S4) Pelvic splanchnic nerves Excitatory effect on Detrusor muscle Inhibitory to the vesical sphincter. Sympathetic Fibers (T10-L2) Inferior mesenteric plexus Hypogastric plexus Inhibitory effect on Detrusor muscle Motor action on vesical sphincter Somatic Nerve (S1, S2, S3) Pudendal nerve Supplies external urethral sphincter, which is under voluntary control
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with sharp pain and swelling in her right buttock and thigh after falling on her side, leading to difficulty sitting and walking. Examination shows swelling, tenderness, and bruising over the right buttock, with no deformity, dislocation, or neurological deficits, indicating a possible hematoma. What is the origin of the affected artery?

options.A: Anterior division of the internal iliac artery
options.B: Posterior division of the internal iliac artery
options.C: Anterior division of the obturator artery
options.D: Posterior division of the obturator artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Posterior division of the internal iliac artery Explanation: The scenario describes a hematoma resulting from trauma to the Superior gluteal artery , which is a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery . Superior Gluteal Artery Origin Branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery. Course Supply Superficial Branch: Gluteus maximus Deep Branch: Gluteus medius Gluteus minimus Obturator artery : Branch of the internal iliac artery Divides (at obturator foramen) into: Anterior (medial) and posterior (lateral) branches. Acetabular branch (posterior division) passes through the acetabular notch (supplying the fat in the acetabular fossa) and sends a twig to the head of the femur along the round ligament.
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with rectal bleeding and changes in bowel habits. The physician evaluates the rectal anatomy to determine the best surgical approach. Which part of the rectum is covered by peritoneum only on the anterior aspect?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Middle 1/3rd Explanation: Middle third of the Rectum is covered by the peritoneum only on the anterior aspect. Part of Rectum Peritoneal Relation Upper 1/3rd (Option A) Covered with peritoneum on the anterior and lateral aspects. Middle 1/3rd (Option B) Covered only on the anterior aspect. Lower 1/3rd (Option C) Devoid of peritoneum Visceral Relations of Rectum: Anterior Relations: Part of Rectum Male Female Upper 2/3rd Rectovesical pouch (coils of intestine and sigmoid colon) Rectouterine pouch (coils of intestine and sigmoid colon) Lower 1/3rd Base of the urinary bladder Ureters (terminal parts) Seminal vesicles Vas deferens (ampullae) Prostate Vagina (lower part) Posterior Relations (Same in both the sexes) : In the Midline On each side of the Midline Lower three pieces of the sacrum Coccyx Anococcygeal raphe Ganglion impar Median sacral vessels Superior rectal artery Fascia of Waldeyer Pyriformis Coccygeus Levator ani Sympathetic chains Anterior primary rami of S3, S4, S5, and coccygeal nerve Pelvic splanchnic nerves Lateral sacral vessels
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman presents with faecal incontinence, particularly during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or lifting heavy objects. MRI reveals atrophy in a muscle responsible for maintaining the anorectal angle. What’s the likely muscle involved in this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Puborectalis Explanation: Puborectalis muscle , part of the levator ani muscle, forms a sling around the anorectal junction and is crucial for maintaining the anorectal angle. Dysfunction or atrophy of this muscle can lead to faecal incontinence , especially during increases in intra-abdominal pressure. Resting Tone is mainly provided by Internal Anal Sphincter (IAS) Relaxed External anal sphincter (EAS) and Puborectalis muscle Weakness of External anal Sphincter, Internal anal Sphincter, Puborectalis muscle. Anorectal Ring Muscles Muscle Description Function Significance Internal Anal Sphincter (Option D) Thickened, terminal portion of the inner circular smooth muscle layer of the large intestine. Provides continuous resting tone to the anal canal through sympathetic innervation. Dysfunction can lead to faecal incontinence. External Anal Sphincter (Option A) Main bulk of the anal sphincter complex and is primarily made of striated muscle. Allows voluntary contro l over defecation; allows sustained contraction. Important for voluntary faecal control Conjoint Longitudinal Muscle (Option B) Layer between internal and external anal sphincters; continuous with the outer longitudinal smooth muscle of the rectum. Contracts during defecation , shortening and widening the anal canal, facilitating faecal passage. Plays a role in defecation; age-related decline in muscle fibres can impact function. Puborectalis (Option C) Sling muscle part of the levator ani muscle , surrounding the anorectal junction. Maintains the anorectal angle. Critical for faecal continence
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 46-year-old female reports intermittent rectal bleeding and a feeling of fullness during bowel movements. She has a history of constipation and obesity. Examination reveals internal haemorrhoids. Which of the following options correctly describes their characteristics concerning location and nerve supply? Presence of a visible thrombus in the anal region Ability to manually reduce the mass. Located below the dentate line, covered by anoderm. Innervated by pelvic splanchnic nerves; generally painless.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 2,4 Explanation: Hemorrhoids are variceal enlargement of the submucosal anal and perianal venous plexuses. They are divided into internal and external piles. Internal Hemorrhoids or True piles are usually painless and occur above the dentate line which bleed on straining during defecation. Type of piles Internal Hemorrhoids External Hemorrhoids Location Above pectinate line Below pectinate line Contributing Vein Main tributaries and radicals of Superior rectal vein Tributaries of Inferior rectal vein Common Site 3, 7 and 11 o’clock positions of the anal wall, in the lithotomy position No such common site. Pain Painless (as innervated by splanchnic nerves ) (Statement 4) Painful (innervated by somatic nerves) Bleeding Bleeds on straining at stool Do not bleed on straining Points to know Initially, they are contained within the anal canal (1st degree) , later, they expand and protrude during defecation (2nd degree), and finally, they stay protruded (3rd degree). 2nd-degree piles can be manually reduced if they are prolapsed and not thrombosed. (Statement 2) A thrombosed external haemorrhoid appears as a painful, swollen, bluish lump at the anal verge resulting from the rupture of a subcutaneous vein. (Statement 1) These are located below the dentate line and present as tense hematomas at the anal margin (perianal hematomas). (Statement 3)
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 33-year-old woman in labour is experiencing discomfort and perianal pain and is scheduled to receive a pudendal nerve block. Which anatomical landmarks should the clinician identify to locate the pudendal nerve accurately?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Ischial spine Explanation: In the pudendal nerve block , the nerve is infiltrated with a local anaesthetic at the point where it crosses the ischial spine using a needle inserted through the vaginal wall, directed by a finger. It aids in achieving almost painless vaginal or forceps deliveries and is also helpful for minor surgeries involving the vagina and perineum. When a bilateral pudendal block is administered, it results in a loss of the anal reflex (saddle anaesthesia), relaxation of the pelvic floor muscles , and diminished sensation in the vulva and lower third of the vagina. Fig: Ischial spine landmark Fig: Pudendal nerve block Lesser sciatic notch (Option A) is the area where the pudendal nerve exits the gluteal region and enters the pudendal canal. It's not easily accessible for the nerve block. Pubic symphysis (Option B): Administering the block here would not accurately target the pudendal nerve and is unlikely to deliver the intended analgesic effect for perineal pain. Greater sciatic notch (Option C) is the point from which the pudendal nerve enters the gluteal region; it is not the preferred site for nerve block.
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes the X, Y, and Z listed below?

options.A: Posterior rami of S1, S2, S3
options.B: Anterior rami of S1, S2, S3
options.C: Posterior rami of S2, S3, S4
options.D: Anterior rami of S2, S3, S4

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Anterior rami of S2, S3, S4 Explanation: The given image depicts the origin of the pudendal nerve , which is formed in the pelvis by the anterior rami of sacral plexus S2, S3 and S4. Sacral plexus is formed by the anterior portion of the L4 nerve , the entire L5 nerve, and the S1, S2, and S3 nerves. These nerves then divide into anterior and posterior rami. Anterior rami: Nerve Root & Nerve To Supplies (L4, L5, S1) Nerve to Quadratus Femoris Quadratus femoris Inferior gemellus Hip joint (L5, S1, S2) Nerve to Obturator Internus Obturator internus Superior gemellus (S2, S3, S4) Pudendal nerve Genital skin, External genital organs Muscles of the perineum (S3, S4) Perforating cutaneous nerve Small area of skin in the gluteal area (L4, L5, S1, S2, S3) Tibial part of the sciatic nerve. Hamstrings All muscles of the calf and the sole (S1, S2) Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh Skin at the back of the thigh Posterior rami : Nerve Root & Nerve To Supplies (L4, L5, S1) Superior Gluteal Nerve Gluteus medius, Gluteus minimus Tensor fascia lata (L5, S1, S2) Inferior Gluteal Nerve Gluteus maximus (L4, L5, S1, S2) Common Peroneal Part of the Sciatic Nerve Evertors of foot Dorsiflexors of ankle joint and extensor digitorum brevis
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic perineal pain and numbness following a difficult vaginal delivery. The clinician suspects entrapment of the nerve supplying sensation to the perineum. Through which foramina does this nerve exit and re-enter the pelvis? → Obturator foramen → Greater sciatic foramen, → Lesser sciatic foramen → Lesser sciatic foramen
questions.explanation: → Lesser sciatic foramen Correct Answer: D) Greater sciatic foramen → Lesser sciatic foramen Explanation: Pudendal nerve originates in the pelvis from the anterior rami of the S2, S3 and S4 nerves of the sacral plexus. It enters the gluteal region through the greater sciatic notch, curves behind the ischial spine for a brief distance, and exits the gluteal area by passing into the lesser sciatic foramen.
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 62-year-old female presents with persistent pelvic pain and urinary incontinence. Imaging reveals a mass in the pelvic region compressing nearby blood vessels, raising suspicion of internal iliac artery involvement. Which of the following is not a branch of the internal iliac artery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Deep circumflex iliac artery Explanation: Deep circumflex iliac artery originates from the external iliac artery, not the internal iliac artery. Lateral sacral artery (Option A) is a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery , supplying the sacral region. Uterine artery (Option B) branches from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery and supplies the uterus. Internal pudendal artery (Option C) also arises from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, it supplies the perineum and external genitalia. Common iliac artery is formed by the bifurcation of the abdominal aorta at the L4 vertebra and divides into the external and internal iliac arteries. External iliac artery, after giving off its branches, continues as the femoral artery, while the internal iliac artery splits into anterior and posterior divisions . Artery Branches Supplies External Iliac Artery Deep circumflex iliac artery Muscles attached to the iliac crest Inferior epigastric artery Muscles and overlying skin of rectus sheath Internal Iliac Artery (Anterior Division) Superior vesical artery Urinary bladder’s superior surface Muscular wall of ductus deferens Obturator artery Medial thigh Middle rectal artery Muscle coats of rectum Prostate Seminal vesicles Inferior Vesical artery Urinary bladder Prostate seminal vesicle The lower part of the ureter Inferior gluteal artery Gluteal region Internal Pudendal artery Perineum region Vaginal artery Vagina and base of the urinary bladder Uterine artery Vagina and uterus Internal Iliac Artery (Posterior Division) (Mnemonic - SIL) S uperior Gluteal artery Muscles of the gluteal region I liolumbar artery Iliacus Muscles of back Cauda equina L ateral sacral artery Cauda equina Back muscles of the sacrum
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with urinary retention and pelvic discomfort. A digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged prostate gland. During surgery to relieve the obstruction, the urologist must take care to avoid damaging the structures that separate the prostate from the rectum. Which of the following structures separates the prostate gland from the rectum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Denonvilliers’ fascia Explanation: The structure that separates the prostate gland from the rectum is the Rectovesical Fascia (also known as Denonvilliers' Fascia ). It extends from the floor of the rectovesical pouch to the perineal body. Waldeyer’s fascia (Option A) is a connective tissue by which the rectum (ampulla) is attached to the sacrum and coccyx. The superficial fascia of the anterior abdominal wall is divided into: A superficial fatty layer, Camper’s fascia (Option D) A deep membranous layer, Scarpa’s fascia (Option B)
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with intermittent abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, and occasional rectal bleeding is scheduled for a sigmoidoscopy. The cannula is inserted in the left lateral position to avoid injuring the rectal folds that are present against the concavities of the rectum. Which of the following statements regarding these folds is inaccurate?

options.A: First fold is situated near the rectosigmoid junction.
options.C: Third fold is located at the upper end of the ampulla.
options.D: They are flattened in a distended rectum.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) They are flattened in a distended rectum. Explanation: In this case, the cannula is inserted laterally during the sigmoidoscopy to prevent injury to the permanent, transverse folds referred to as Houston's valves , which are more prominent during distension. Two Types of Folds in the Rectum: Longitudinal Houston’s valve (Transverse or horizontal folds or plicae transversales) Temporary folds Situated in the lower part of an empty rectum. Obliterated by distension Permanent folds (Option B) Situated against the concavities of the lateral curvatures of the rectum. More prominent by distension (Option D) Types of Houston’s Valves: Types First Transverse Fold Second Transverse Fold Third Transverse Fold Fourth Transverse Fold Site Near the upper end, close to the rectosigmoid junction. (Option A) Above the third fold (2.5cm) At the level of the upper end of the ampulla. (Option C) Below the third valve (2.5cm) Wall of Projection Right or left wall Left wall (upper lateral curvature) Anterior and right wall (middle lateral curvature) Left wall (lower lateral curvature)
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with perianal pain and bleeding during bowel movements. The region affected is supplied by a vessel that arises from the internal iliac system and supplies the lower anal canal. Which of the following arteries is the direct source of this vessel?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Internal pudendal artery Explanation : Internal pudendal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery , and it gives rise to the inferior rectal artery that supplies the lower third of the rectum and the anal canal. Arterial Supply of the Rectum: Artery Source Supplies Superior Rectal Artery Branch of the inferior mesenteric artery (Option A) Upper two-thirds of the rectum Middle Rectal Artery Branch of the internal iliac artery Middle third of the rectum Inferior Rectal Artery Branch of the internal pudendal artery (Option B) Distal rectum & anal canal Venous Drainage of the Rectum: Vein Drains Into Region Drained Superior Rectal Vein Inferior mesenteric vein Upper two-thirds of the rectum Middle Rectal Vein Internal iliac vein Middle third of the rectum Inferior Rectal Vein Internal pudendal vein Anal canal & distal rectum Superior gluteal artery (Option D) is a branch of the internal iliac artery, supplying the gluteal muscles, but it does not directly contribute to the rectal blood supply.
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with painful anal swelling and bleeding. External haemorrhoids are diagnosed, and the physician explains the pain is due to somatic innervation below a specific anatomical landmark in the anal canal. Which of the following separates the areas of somatic and visceral nerve supply in the anal canal?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pectinate line Explanation: Anal canal is divided into upper and lower parts by pectinate line or dentate line (teeth shaped), which forms embryological, neurovascular and histological boundaries. Upper part is supplied by the autonomic nervous system (painless) and the lower by somatic nerves (painful). Lower ends of the anal column are joined by short transverse folds of mucous membranes known as anal valves . Mucosal depressions above these valves are called anal sinuses. Together, the anal valves form a transverse line encircling the anal canal, known as the pectinate line. Features Upper Anal Canal Lower Anal Canal Development Endodermal Ectodermal Epithelium Simple columnar Stratified squamous Nerve supply Autonomic nerves Painless Sympathetic (L1, L2) Parasympathetic (S2, S3, S4) Somatic nerves Painful Sympathetic (S2, S, S4) Arterial supply Superior rectal artery Inferior rectal artery Venous drainage Superior rectal vein draining into the portal system Inferior rectal vein draining into caval system Lymphatic system Internal iliac nodes Superficial inguinal nodes Common Type of Hemorrhoids Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids White line of Hilton (Option A) is located at the junction between the subcutaneous portion of the external anal sphincter and the lower border of the internal anal sphincter. It marks the boundary of the mucocutaneous junction. Anorectal junction (Option B) is defined by the forward convexity of the rectal perineal flexure, located just below the tip of the coccyx. Here, the rectal ampulla narrows as it passes through the pelvic diaphragm, aligning with the apex of the prostate in males. Iliopectineal line (Option C) is a ridge located on the inner surface of the pelvis, created by the fusion of the ilium and pubis, extending from the pubic symphysis to the arcuate line of the ilium. This anatomical landmark is significant in clinical practice for directing pelvic surgeries and evaluating conditions that impact the pelvic organs.
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal

questions.question: A 73-year-old male presents with rectal pain, and there is concern for rectal metastasis, given his history of prostate cancer. Which lymph nodes are most likely involved in the lymphatic drainage of the region marked ‘X’ in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Internal iliac lymph nodes Explanation: The ‘X’ marked region is the lower part of the rectum . Internal iliac lymph nodes are primarily involved in the lymphatic drainage of the lower part of the rectum. Lymphatic Drainage of the Rectum and Anal Canal: Region Lymphatic Drainage Upper half of the rectum Inferior mesenteric nodes via pararectal and sigmoid nodes (Option B) Lower half of the rectum & upper anal canal Internal iliac nodes Anal Canal (below the pectinate line) Superficial inguinal lymph nodes (Option C) Lymphatic drainage of anal canal" data-author="NA" data-hash="7679" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="500" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/q4TLKhg3WfXJ9WXFVQtX1743852721.png" width="500" /> Para-aortic lymph nodes (Option A) are situated along the abdominal aorta, mainly at the L1 and L2 vertebral levels. They are responsible for draining lymph from the pelvic organs, lower extremities, and abdominal viscera, including the kidneys, ureters, and sections of the gastrointestinal tract.
questions.chapter_heading: Pelvis Perineum Rectum And Anal Canal
